history.content:
<md>If you really interned at a FAANG, you should know very well that no one gets $1 mill after 4-5 years experience (save for Andrej Karpathy and few other ML rockstars) 

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Berkeley has a wonderful tool called the First Destination Survey https://career.berkeley.edu/survey/survey

Here you can see in 2020 the (self reported) quartiles for eecs salaries were:

Lower Quartile $110,000
Median Salary $122,000
Upper Quartile $130,000

Nowhere close to half a million.</md>

<md>If you really interned at a FAANG, you should know very well that no one gets $1 mill after 4-5 years experience (save for Andrej Karpathy and few other ML rockstars) 
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Berkeley has a wonderful tool called the First Destination Survey https://career.berkeley.edu/survey/survey

Here you can see in 2020 the (self reported) quartiles for eecs salaries were:

Lower Quartile $110,000
Median Salary $122,000
Upper Quartile $130,000

Nowhere close to half a million.</md>
If you really interned at a FAANG, you should know very well that no one gets $1 mill after 4-5 years experience (save for Andrej Karpathy and few other ML rockstars)

children.subject: https://www.levels.fyi/ is pretty accurate

The pandemic has elevated salaries and total compensation significantly due to inflation and the rise in tech valuations. For example, I know several new grads working at Snapchat who are literally raking in around $1m a year, due to their equity appreciation the past year. And then aren't even 2 years out of college yet.

You are including stock price fluctuation into someones TC, which is common when you are 2-3 years out. I know people at coinbase/roblox 2 years out of Berkeley making "millions" too due to the huge growth post-ipo. Your question is about 500k tc as a new grad, which wouldn't include stock growth know because the amount of RSUs/option strike price you get is determined the day you join to the current strike price.

FWIW: 500k is even rare for rock star return interns at top quant places. I am at a top high frequency trading company right now and even the best returning quant research new grads are 400k to a bit above 500k. You won't get that TC in silicon valley right out of college. Please do your research before posting because this post comes off very poorly and continues to perpetrate the negative image EECS has.

woops a lot of typos: "Your question is about 500k tc as a new grad, which wouldn't include stock growth know because the amount of RSUs/option you get and the strike price is determined the day you join, so you don't get any stock appreciation.
You guys do realize that demanding higher TC benefits all of us right? If all new grads demand $500k then they will have no choice but to pay $500k.
Congrats Anon Comp, you just discovered collective bargaining
Theyd hire less too lol

Everyone is aware of collective bargaining, but few actually keep that in mind when negotiating an offer. I've seen so many new grads just accept quickly the first thing that's given to them. It never hurts to ask for a bit more, and that benefits all of us in the long run.
Since when was $500k a "bit more"? You're right that new grads should probably try to negotiate, but to that extent would be absurd.

CS/SWE and everything peripheral is so popular atm that I can only expect that the labor market for SWEs is some years away from being totally saturated; I don't know how well one can predict what salaries will look like 4-5 years out beyond the expectation that compensation for entry/mid level positions is gonna take a dive.
sounds like you never had an actual swe job before if this post isn't satire

<md>Around 60% would go to taxes for 1 mil salary. If I were OP, I would focus less on the salary on more about personal development and the experience you get from your job, unless you or your family really needs the money. 150-200K is plenty for living in the Bay Area.</md>
200k is not even enough to buy a home in the bay area...
<md>200k isn't enough to buy a home in Mississippi too... But still plenty enough to live off of.</md>

I mean, factoring in student loans, rent, food, car loan, contributions to retirement, etc., you will have very little left at the end of the month and will have to live the life of a pauper. And god forbid if you intend to start a family.
<md>Damn Karthik, how tf do you always get so many upvotes? You got burner accounts or something?</md>
It is I, a Karthik burner account
@anonymous scale everyone on piazza except you is me

I like your mindset. If you look at the berkeley stats for seniors graduating with cs the average salary is 133K iirc. So probably with bonuses and stocks more or less than 150K-200K is realistic. However, the best thing to do is keep switching jobs like every 2-3 yrs and negotiate a larger compensation than your last job. You become more valuable because of the experience you have at different companies, make new connections and learn a lot of new tech. You could work you way up pretty high with this technique, though 1 million a year is kinda far fetched for swe unless you literally are at like the top level for managing stuff, i think at that point you are no longer coding just calling the shots and making business moves. If that’s something you want to do you just have to try your best to get promoted, which gets harder every time you get promoted since there are less spots to fill in. I think a good alternative is using your money to make more money. Investing in real estate, stocks, your own business, etc. Also I can  imagine if you were able to rack up a 1 million dollar salary and how much of that would go to taxes, probably half haha? Good luck, on your dream, I also have a similar goal! Work hard and you can do it!
You had me in the first half 😂😂
Can't tell if sarcasm or serious. But it seems like entreneurship is easier to achieve that level of earnings rather than grinding up the corporate ladder..
Even better if you can get a small loan of a million dollars from your parents
I would recommend starting a blockchain fintech AI/ML cloud PaaS IaaS SaaS business for the most sure-shot way to hit that TC level within a few years 💪💯😤.
Full time roles typically should be at least double the intern salary so $2-3 mm will suffice
<md>Sounds like a reasonable thing to shoot for. Where u interning at? Referral pls?</md>
starting (intern) shooting guard of the six-time NBA champion chicago bulls
<md>more realistic option: https://vm.tiktok.com/ZMdq3HDKA/</md>
$1M sounds reasonable for an internship, probably should ask for higher for full-time
Please give me a referral when you get the 1M job. You could take 20% markup.
Nature is healing
We (STEM students) are the virus
An EECS 101 dogpile like the good old days? Maybe the pandemic really is coming to an end

history.content:
I am a rising senior and am wondering about the average salaries of new grads for EECS. I am hearing that on the high end is $400k (including stock, bonus, etc.) and the lower end around $300k. I also have no interest in working as a quant for hedge funds, since they tend to have long hours (so the $400k a year actually becomes like $200k a year because of the 80hrs/week you put in). I know inflation has put the salaries really out of whack - in fact I know several people in the industry switching to a new job because the new offers offer at least a 20%+ bump in salary due to the inflation alone. But is $500k something realistic for me to aim for? I am hoping to start with $500k TC out of college, then in the next 4 years gradually work my way up, hopefully aiming for $1mil TC 4-5 years from now. I have interned at FAANG companies and a startup the past two summers, have a clean transcript, etc., so I consider myself in the top 10 percentile of new grads.

Also if you are a new grad and have gotten and offer please do feel free to share.
history.subject: Average TC for new grads? $500k realistic?
